        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: &ref_1
        test_description: Has no spelling errors
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out
          different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations
          in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher
          level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate collaboratively within specific networks to perform
          diverse functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259] (Context).
          Any alterations in these genes can modify their functional roles,
          which, on a broader scale, can influence biological processes related
          to diseases [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To understand how genes
          affect complex traits, it is critical to comprehend the regulation of
          gene expression across various cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This understanding can potentially
          lead to the development of more effective treatments
          [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Earlier
          research has identified diverse regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including the genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]
          (Content). By combining functional genomics data with GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890], the
          identification of transcriptional mechanisms has been enhanced. These
          mechanisms, when disrupted, often lead to pathology specific to tissue
          and cell lineage [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105] (Conclusion).
      success: true

          - pass: true

                input_words = len(input.strip().split())

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate within context-specific networks to perform various
          functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Changes in these
          genes can alter their functional roles and, on a broader scale, impact
          biological processes related to disease
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this regard, understanding how
          genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic
          comprehension of expression regulation across diverse cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This understanding should
          subsequently lead to the development of improved treatments
          [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior
          studies have described various regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including the genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          The integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced
          the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when disrupted,
          often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology
          [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate within context-specific networks to execute various
          functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these
          genes can modify their functional roles and, on a broader scale,
          impact biological processes relevant to disease
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this regard, understanding how
          genes affect complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension
          of expression regulation across diverse cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This understanding should
          subsequently lead to the development of enhanced treatments
          [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Earlier
          studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          The integration of functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation
          of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate within specialized networks to perform distinct
          functions, and alterations in these genes can modify their roles,
          ultimately impacting disease-related biological processes
          [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6] (Context). To comprehend how genes
          affect complex traits, it is crucial to understand the regulation of
          gene expression across diverse cell types. This understanding could
          pave the way for enhanced treatments [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489] (Content).
          Previous research has delineated various regulatory DNA elements and
          genetic influences on gene expression across different tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Moreover, the integration of functional genomics data and genome-wide
          association study (GWAS) data has improved the detection of
          transcriptional mechanisms. When these mechanisms are disrupted, they
          often result in disease specific to certain tissues and cell lineages
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890;
          @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]
          (Conclusion).
      success: true

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          In the intricate world of genetics, genes do not operate in isolation
          but rather interact within context-specific networks to perform
          various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. These
          interactions can be altered by variations in the genes themselves,
          leading to changes in their functional roles and potentially
          influencing biological processes that are relevant to disease
          development [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To comprehend how these
          genetic interactions affect complex traits, it is essential to
          understand the regulatory mechanisms of gene expression across diverse
          cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This
          understanding could ultimately pave the way for improved therapeutic
          interventions [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Past research has shed light on
          various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;
          @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] and
          the impact of genetic variations on gene expression across different
          tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. By integrating functional
          genomics data with genome-wide association study (GWAS) data,
          researchers have made significant strides in identifying the
          transcriptional mechanisms that, when disrupted, often lead to tissue-
          and cell lineage-specific diseases [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there is still a substantial
          knowledge gap in understanding how these mechanisms can be leveraged
          for drug repurposing and identification of novel therapeutic targets.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes cooperate within specialized networks to execute various
          functions, a process that can be influenced by genetic variations
          [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. These variations can alter the
          genes' operational roles and consequently impact biological processes
          related to diseases. To comprehend how genes contribute to complex
          traits, it is essential to understand the regulation of gene
          expression across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. Such
          knowledge can potentially lead to the development of more effective
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Past research has outlined various regulatory DNA elements, including
          the genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The
          integration of functional genomics data and Genome-Wide Association
          Studies (GWAS) data has enhanced the identification of transcriptional
          mechanisms [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890]. When these mechanisms are disrupted, they
          often lead to disease conditions specific to certain tissues and cell
          lineages [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. This underscores the need for further
          research into the intricate interplay of gene networks and their
          impact on disease processes.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved

          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate in specialized networks to perform various functions,
          with their roles potentially altered by genetic variations, thereby
          impacting disease-associated biological processes [@pmid:19104045;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. This sets the
          stage for the necessity to understand how these genes influence
          complex traits, a task that requires an in-depth comprehension of gene
          expression regulation across different cell types. This understanding
          holds promise for enhancing treatment strategies
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous research has revealed
          various regulatory DNA elements, including the effects of genetics on
          gene expression across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;
          @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The integration of functional genomics
          data and Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) data has significantly
          advanced the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms. When
          these mechanisms are disrupted, they often lead to pathology specific
          to particular tissues and cell lineages
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890;
          @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].
          However, a comprehensive understanding of how these genetic
          associations are projected through gene expression patterns remains
          elusive, highlighting a critical gap that this manuscript aims to
          address.

          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate collectively within specific networks to perform various
          functions, a dynamic that is influenced by genetic variations
          [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. These variations can modify the
          roles of individual genes and, on a broader scale, impact biological
          processes related to disease. Understanding how genes contribute to
          complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of gene
          expression regulation across diverse cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge can then pave the way
          for the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior research has identified
          various regulatory DNA elements, including those that influence gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;
          @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The integration of functional genomics
          data with Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) data has enhanced the
          identification of these regulatory transcriptional mechanisms
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890]. When these
          mechanisms are dysregulated, they often lead to pathology specific to
          certain tissues and cell lineages [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. This highlights the need for further
          investigation into the interplay between genetic variations and gene
          expression regulation across different cell types, a gap in knowledge
          that this manuscript aims to address.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;

          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

          Genes operate within specific networks to perform various functions,
          with alterations in these genes potentially influencing their
          functional roles and, consequently, disease-related biological
          processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. This sets the stage for our
          understanding of how genes impact complex traits, which necessitates a
          mechanistic comprehension of gene expression regulation across diverse
          cell types. This understanding, in turn, is expected to pave the way
          for enhanced treatment strategies [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior
          research has delineated various regulatory DNA elements, including the
          genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Furthermore, the integration of functional genomics data with GWAS
          data has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms.
          When these mechanisms are disrupted, they often lead to tissue- and
          cell lineage-specific diseases [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. This study aims to fill the knowledge
          gap in understanding the relationship between gene expression
          patterns, disease etiology, and drug mechanisms.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: &ref_24
        test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an
          effective approach to identify these biological processes is the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing
          whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.
      response:
        output: >-
          With the widespread availability of gene expression data across
          numerous tissues, an effective approach to identifying biological
          processes is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS)
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. These
          studies integrate expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data,
          providing a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. The basis of
          TWAS is to test whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has proven highly successful, not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          predicting disease risk (using polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, a limitation of TWAS is that it
          operates at the individual gene level, thereby failing to capture more
          complex interactions at the network level.
      success: true

                needed because

                references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


                count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])

                return (count / len(references) > 0.50)

            score: 1
            reason: Assertion passed
            assertion: &ref_27
              type: python
              value: >
                import re


                input = context["vars"]["content"]


                references = {
                  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
                  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
                  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
                  "@pmid:33931583",
                  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
                  "@pmid:31036433",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
                  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
                }


                # keep only references that are present in the input (this is
                needed because

                #  references might be removed from the input in some cases)

                references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


                # capture current references in the output using a regex

                output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)


                n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not
                in references])

                return (n_fake_refs == 0)
        assertion: null

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate within specific networks to perform various functions,
          and alterations in these genes can modify their roles and impact
          biological processes related to diseases [@pmid:19104045;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To understand
          how genes affect complex traits, it's essential to comprehend how gene
          expression is regulated across different cell types. This knowledge
          can potentially lead to the development of improved treatments
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Past research has detailed various
          regulatory DNA elements, including the impact of genetic variations on
          gene expression across diverse tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;
          @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The integration of functional genomics
          data with Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) data has enhanced the
          identification of transcriptional mechanisms. When these mechanisms
          are disrupted, they often lead to pathology specific to certain
          tissues and cell lineages [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there is still a need for more
          comprehensive understanding of these complex gene interactions and
          their implications for disease treatment and drug development.

          Genes operate within context-specific networks to perform various
          functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259], with alterations in
          these genes potentially changing their roles and influencing
          disease-related biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. To comprehend how genes affect

          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including the genetic impact on gene

          the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. When these
          mechanisms are disrupted, they often lead to pathology that is
          specific to tissue and cell lineage [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, our understanding of these
          complex mechanisms and their roles in disease pathology remains
          incomplete, thus warranting further investigation.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          With the accessibility of gene expression data across various tissues,
          the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) presents an effective
          approach to identify these biological processes. This approach
          integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, providing
          a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS)
          findings. TWAS is dependent on the testing of whether disruptions in
          gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
          variants and human diseases. These methods have proven highly
          effective not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level, but also in predicting disease risk through
          polygenic scores and in drug repurposing tasks. However, it should be
          noted that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which does not
          account for more complex interactions at the network level.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of

          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has offered
          a wealth of resources for understanding biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]
          (Context). A popular tool to decipher these processes is the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide insights
          into the mechanisms behind genome-wide association study (GWAS)
          results. Essentially, TWAS investigates if alterations in gene
          regulation mediate the link between genetic variations and human
          diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has proven fruitful not only in elucidating disease causes at
          the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
          predicting disease risk (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] (Content). However, the current TWAS model
          focuses on individual genes, thereby overlooking potential intricate
          interactions at the network level, a gap that our manuscript aims to
          address (Conclusion).

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          The advent of gene expression data across a multitude of tissues has
          opened new avenues in biological research [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. Among the methods developed to
          leverage this data, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS)
          has proven effective. TWAS integrates data on expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) to provide mechanistic explanations for findings
          from genome-wide association studies (GWAS). It does so by examining
          the potential mediating role of gene regulatory mechanisms in the
          relationship between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has been instrumental not only in understanding disease
          origins at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
          predicting disease risk (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these successes, a significant gap
          remains in our understanding: TWAS operates at the level of individual
          genes, thereby overlooking potentially intricate interactions
          occurring at the network level.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug

          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          The advent of gene expression data from various tissues has opened new
          avenues in genetic studies [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          prominent method to explore these biological processes is the
          Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS), which leverages
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to interpret the
          findings of Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) mechanistically.
          This method investigates the role of gene regulatory disruptions in
          mediating the relationship between genetic variations and human
          diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has proved highly effective in deciphering disease origins at
          the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease
          risk using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and
          repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these successes, a
          limitation of TWAS is its focus on individual genes, which overlooks
          potential complex interactions at the network level. This paper
          addresses this gap by exploring the implications of such network-level
          interactions.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;

          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing

          network level.

      response:
        output: >-
          With the broad availability of gene expression data across various
          tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged
          as an effective approach for identifying biological processes. This
          method integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          offer a mechanistic interpretation of Genome-Wide Association Studies
          (GWAS) findings. The TWAS approach tests whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic
          variants and human diseases. These strategies have proven highly
          successful, not only in comprehending disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level but also in predicting disease risk (through
          polygenic scores) and in tasks related to drug repurposing. However, a
          limitation of TWAS is its focus on the individual gene level, which
          overlooks more complex interactions occurring at the network level.

          With the advent of gene expression data across a range of tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s13040-020-00216-9], new
          methods have been developed to identify biological processes. One such
          method, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), utilizes
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to interpret the
          mechanisms behind Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) findings. TWAS
          assesses whether changes in gene regulation can explain the link
          between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This

          the level of the transcriptome [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease
          risk using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and
          repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at
          the individual gene level and therefore does not account for more
          intricate interactions at the network level. This gap in our
          understanding underscores the need for new approaches that can capture
          these complex interactions.

          "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
          "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
          "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
          "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
          "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
          "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
          "@pmid:33931583",
          "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
          "@pmid:31036433",
          "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
          "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
        }


        # keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed
        because

        #  references might be removed from the input in some cases)

        references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


        # capture current references in the output using a regex

        output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)


        n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in
        references])

        return (n_fake_refs == 0)
