      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a
          powerful tool to investigate the influence of genetic variations on
          human diseases, by exploring the potential mediation of these
          associations through alterations in gene regulation
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has proven highly effective in elucidating disease origins at
          the transcriptomic level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], in predicting
          disease risk using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w],
          and in repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundant
          availability of gene expression data across various tissues further
          enhances the utility of TWAS, enabling it to integrate expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic insights
          into genome-wide association study (GWAS) results
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
          However, a limitation of TWAS is that it operates at the level of
          individual genes, and thus does not account for more intricate
          interactions that occur at the network level. This highlights a
          knowledge gap that necessitates further research to enhance our
          understanding of complex genetic networks in disease etiology.

          for the use of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) as an

          providing a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. However, TWAS
          operates at the individual gene level and does not account for complex
          network-level interactions. The method involves testing whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Despite this

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_58
      response:
        output: >-
          The widespread accessibility of gene expression data across various
          tissues has opened a new avenue for understanding biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          prevalent method, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS),
          leverages this data to provide insights into the mechanisms underlying
          the associations found in genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This
          powerful tool operates by investigating whether changes in gene
          regulation mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human
          diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. The
          application of TWAS has proven to be highly successful in enhancing
          our understanding of disease origins at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], in
          predicting disease risk using polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and in repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, a notable limitation of TWAS is that
          it operates at the level of individual genes, thereby overlooking
          potentially significant, complex interactions at the network level.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)

          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not

          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

          With the wealth of gene expression data available across various
          tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) serves as an
          effective method for identifying biological processes. TWAS integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic
          explanation for Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) findings.
          However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not
          account for more complex interactions at the network level. It tests
          whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          relationship between genetic variants and human diseases. This
          approach has been highly successful not only in understanding disease

          disease-risk (polygenic scores) and repurposing drugs.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug

          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_58
      response:
        output: >-
          In the era of abundant gene expression data across various tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an
          effective tool for identifying biological processes. TWAS integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer mechanistic
          explanations for genetic findings associated with diseases. Despite
          its effectiveness, TWAS operates on an individual gene level, thus not
          fully encompassing the intricate interactions that occur at the
          network level. TWAS's methodology hinges on testing if disruptions in
          gene regulatory mechanisms serve as a bridge between genetic
          variations and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has been notably successful in
          not only deepening our understanding of disease causation at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433], but also in predicting disease risk (polygenic
          scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these achievements, there remains a
          gap in capturing complex gene interactions at the network level, which
          our manuscript aims to address.

          Considering the abundant availability of gene expression data across
          various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS)
          serves as an effective approach to identify biological processes. TWAS
          incorporates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby
          providing a mechanistic interpretation of Genome-Wide Association
          Study (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS primarily operates at the
          individual gene level, which limits its ability to capture more
          intricate interactions at the network level. TWAS tests the hypothesis
          that perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases. This approach
          has proven to be highly successful, not only in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level but also in predicting disease
          risk through polygenic scores and in drug repurposing tasks.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug

          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of

          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)

      vars: *ref_58
      response:
        output: >-
          The abundance of gene expression data across various tissues offers an
          opportunity to identify biological processes linked to disease and
          drug mechanisms [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1038/s13040-020-00216-9;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776] (Context). A key method for exploring
          these connections is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS),
          which uses expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          interpret the findings of genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This
          approach has proven successful in understanding disease causation at
          the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease
          risk using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and
          repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] (Content). However, TWAS
          primarily focuses on individual genes, neglecting the more intricate
          interactions that occur at the network level. Consequently, there is
          an unmet need to incorporate network-level interactions into genetic
          studies to better elucidate disease processes and drug mechanisms
          (Conclusion).

          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt

        output: >-
          The broad availability of gene expression data across various tissues
          has opened new avenues for understanding biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]
          (Context). One of the effective methods used to identify these
          processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS
          uses expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic explanation for findings from genome-wide association
          studies (GWAS). It operates by testing if changes in gene regulatory
          processes mediate the relationship between genetic variations and
          human diseases. This approach has been tremendously successful in both
          understanding disease origins at the transcriptome level and
          predicting disease risk using polygenic scores. It has also found
          applications in drug repurposing [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367; @pmid:33931583;

          @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618] (Content).
          Nevertheless, TWAS primarily focuses on individual genes, which limits
          its ability to capture more intricate interactions occurring at the
          network level (Conclusion).

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt

        output: >-
          The wealth of gene expression data across various tissues provides a
          robust platform for understanding biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]
          (Context). This data has been harnessed through transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS), which utilize expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to elucidate the mechanisms underpinning
          genetic associations found in genome-wide association studies (GWAS).
          TWAS has been instrumental in exploring how disruptions in gene
          regulation mediate the relationship between genetic variations and
          human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has proven highly successful in
          not only deepening our understanding of disease origins at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433], but also in predicting disease risk (polygenic
          scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] (Content). However, TWAS primarily operates at
          the level of individual genes, thereby failing to account for more
          intricate interactions at the network level, which underscores the
          need for methods that can capture these complex interactions
          (Conclusion).

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_58
      response:
        output: >-
          The abundance of gene expression data across various tissues has
          become readily accessible in recent times [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. This wealth of information has given
          rise to a powerful tool known as the transcription-wide association
          study (TWAS). TWAS utilizes expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to offer mechanistic explanations for findings from genome-wide
          association studies (GWAS). This method has been instrumental in
          elucidating disease origins at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], in
          predicting disease risk through polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and in the repurposing of drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, a limitation of TWAS is that it
          operates at the level of individual genes, thereby failing to capture
          more intricate interactions at the network level. This suggests a
          potential gap in our understanding of how genetic variations influence
          human diseases, highlighting the need for methods that can capture
          these complex network-level interactions.

          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)

          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these

        output: >-
          With the current abundance of gene expression data across various
          tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) presents an
          effective method for identifying biological processes. This approach
          integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, providing
          a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS)
          findings. However, TWAS operates at the level of individual genes and
          fails to capture more intricate interactions at the network level. It
          tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases. These
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level but also in predicting
          disease risk (via polygenic scores) and in drug repurposing tasks.

          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific

          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)

          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not

          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_58
      response:
        output: >-
          The advent of extensive gene expression data across various tissues
          has paved the way for advanced biological process identification
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          commonly employed method for this purpose is the Transcription-Wide
          Association Study (TWAS). This approach utilizes expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer mechanistic explanations
          for findings from genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Despite its
          effectiveness, TWAS primarily operates at the individual gene level,
          failing to account for more intricate network-level interactions. The
          method hinges on testing if alterations in gene regulation mechanisms
          serve as a conduit between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has been instrumental in deciphering disease origins at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, there is a pressing need to enhance
          the scope of TWAS to encapsulate network-level interactions, thereby
          enriching our understanding of complex biological processes and
          disease mechanisms.

          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing

          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_58
      response:
        output: >-
          The extensive availability of gene expression data across various
          tissues sets the stage for a deeper understanding of biological
          processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          prevalent method for deciphering these processes is the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This technique combines
          data on expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) to offer
          mechanistic explanations for findings from genome-wide association
          studies (GWAS). Despite its efficacy, TWAS operates on a single gene
          level and does not account for more intricate network-level
          interactions. The approach hinges on examining whether disturbances in
          gene regulatory mechanisms serve as a bridge between genetic
          variations and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method has proven highly successful in not
          only comprehending disease origins at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433],
          but also in predicting disease risk (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, the limitation of TWAS in capturing
          complex network-level interactions underscores the need for approaches
          that can probe these intricate relationships.
      success: true

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: &ref_76
        test_description: has proper last paragraph structure
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
          module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method
          allows integrating different data modalities into the same
          representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
          perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel method for genetic
          analysis that offers a comprehensive view of gene modules, or groups
          of functionally-related genes, and their influence on complex traits
          (Context). Our approach incorporates different data types into a
          unified analysis, allowing us to discern shared and unique
          transcriptomic properties among traits and predict the impact of drug
          interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common representation. This is accomplished by integrating
          thousands of gene-trait associations from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional profiles from
          LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a low-dimensional
          space derived from public gene expression data on numerous RNA-seq
          samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
          @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We utilize a latent representation defined by
          a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that identifies gene modules under
          certain constraints and preferences for those that align with
          established knowledge (pathways). Our results demonstrate that
          diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
          relevant cell types, and we can identify modules associated with cell
          types in specific disease states or under particular stimuli. Our
          findings using PhenoPLIER were replicated in the Electronic Medical
          Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
          [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. We also
          conducted a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells,
          further validating our module-based approach. Notably, PhenoPLIER
          outperformed single-gene methods in predicting FDA-approved
          drug-disease links, suggesting that gene modules may offer a more
          effective way to examine drug-disease relationships (Content). In
          conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a significant advancement in genetic
          studies by focusing on gene modules rather than individual genes. This
          approach enhances the robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations and can highlight alternative and potentially more
          promising candidate targets, even when known single gene associations
          are not detected. This innovation could lead to a deeper understanding
          of complex diseases and their therapeutic options, signifying a
          paradigm shift in genetic research (Conclusion).
      success: true

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic tool that brings
          a gene module perspective to genetic research. Our method is flexible
          and capable of integrating different data types into one
          representation for a comprehensive analysis. We demonstrate that this
          module perspective can deduce how clusters of functionally-related
          genes affect complex traits, identify shared and unique transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict the influence of pharmacological
          interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER aligns gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses in a shared
          latent representation. To accomplish this, we incorporate thousands of
          gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000) into a
          low-dimensional space, derived from publicly available gene expression
          data from tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach that
          isolates gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this compressed expression space,
          we note that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types, such as T cells with hypothyroidism,
          and corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, among
          others. Notably, PhenoPLIER can utilize models derived from large and
          diverse RNA-seq datasets, allowing us to also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
          conditions. We found that significant module-trait associations in
          PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) were replicated in the Electronic
          Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III (our
          replication cohort). Additionally, we conducted a CRISPR screen to
          analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, observing that trait
          associations were more robust with modules than with individual genes.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links more accurately by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the drugs'
          mechanism of action. This suggests that modules may be more effective
          in examining drug-disease relationships than individual genes.
          Finally, our exploration of the phenotype-module space revealed stable
          trait clusters associated with relevant tissues. In conclusion,
          PhenoPLIER offers a novel approach in interpreting genetic studies by
          focusing on groups of genes that work together in specific cell types
          rather than individual genes. This approach enhances the robustness in
          detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and we demonstrate
          its potential in prioritizing alternative and potentially more
          promising candidate targets, even when known single gene associations
          are not detected. This represents a significant shift in the
          interpretation of genetic studies and has the potential to provide
          mechanistic insights from statistical associations, thereby enhancing
          our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.
      success: true
      score: 1

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In the context of genetic studies, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a
          comprehensive method that adopts a modular approach to understanding
          gene function and interaction. Our method combines various data types
          for a unified analysis, enabling the inference of how
          functionally-linked gene groups influence complex traits, the
          identification of shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics
          among these traits, and the prediction of how drug interventions
          impact gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a shared
          latent representation, integrating thousands of gene-trait
          associations from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug
          transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a low-dimensional space derived
          from extensive public gene expression data
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. This latent
          representation, defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003],
          extracts gene modules under specific constraints, favoring those that
          align with established knowledge. We find that diseases are
          significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell
          types. Additionally, our approach allows for the identification of
          modules linked with cell types under specific conditions or disease
          states. Importantly, we find that our module-trait associations
          replicated in the eMERGE network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and that our module-based method
          outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved
          drug-disease associations, suggesting that modules may be a superior
          means to explore drug-disease relationships. Finally, we reveal stable
          trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, indicating a complex
          relationship between lipids and cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
          neuropsychiatric disorders. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a
          paradigm shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, focusing on
          groups of genes that work together within specific cell types. This
          approach enhances the robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, offering the potential to reveal more promising
          candidate targets for therapeutic interventions and advance our
          understanding of complex diseases.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that
          offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our method's
          flexibility enables the integration of various data types into a
          unified representation for combined analysis. We demonstrate that this
          module perspective can deduce how clusters of functionally-related
          genes affect complex traits, identify shared and unique transcriptomic
          characteristics among traits, and predict the impact of
          pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER
          consolidates gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a shared latent representation. To achieve this, we
          incorporate thousands of gene-trait associations (sourced from
          PhenomeXcan's TWAS [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
          profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049])
          into a low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data
          of tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We employ a
          latent representation, defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003],
          that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those aligning with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          find that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types. For example, hypothyroidism with T
          cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
          hematological assays with specific blood cell types, plasma lipids
          with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different
          brain cell types. Additionally, as PhenoPLIER can utilize models
          derived from extensive and diverse RNA-seq datasets, we can also
          identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
          disease states. We note that significant module-trait associations in
          PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) are replicated in the Electronic
          Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
          [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
          replication cohort). We also conduct a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid
          regulation in HepG2 cells, noting more robust trait associations with
          modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          In comparison to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a superior means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Lastly, exploration
          of the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          conclusion, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together
          to carry out different functions in specific cell types, rather than
          focusing on single genes associated with different complex traits.
          This approach enhances robustness in detecting and interpreting
          genetic associations, and we demonstrate its ability to prioritize
          alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when
          known single gene associations are not detected. This method signifies
          a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, with the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to improve our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.
