      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In the realm of genetic studies, we introduce a novel approach termed
          PhenoPLIER, which utilizes an omnigenic perspective to analyze gene
          modules. This method is flexible, permitting the integration of
          various data types into a unified representation for joint analysis.
          We demonstrate that this approach can deduce the influence of
          functionally-related gene clusters on complex traits, discern shared
          and unique transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict the
          impact of pharmacological perturbations on gene activity. To achieve
          this, PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a shared latent representation. This
          process involves integrating thousands of gene-trait associations from
          PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional
          profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a
          low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on an
          extensive collection of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We employ a
          matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to define a latent representation
          that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those aligning with prior knowledge. By mapping
          gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we reveal
          significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed
          in relevant cell types. Notably, PhenoPLIER's ability to utilize
          models derived from large, heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets allows the
          identification of modules associated with specific cell types under
          particular stimuli or disease states. We found that significant
          module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan replicated in the Electronic
          Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
          [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225].
          Furthermore, our module-based approach outperforms a single-gene
          approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms associated with drug
          actions. This enhanced drug-disease prediction suggests that modules
          may offer a superior means to investigate drug-disease relationships
          than individual genes. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm
          shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. By focusing on groups
          of genes that act together within specific cell types, rather than
          single genes associated with complex traits, we improve the robustness
          of detecting and interpreting genetic associations. Our findings
          illustrate how this approach can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected, thereby deepening our
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
      success: true

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
          offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our approach is
          flexible, allowing for the integration of various data modalities into
          a unified representation for joint analysis. We demonstrate that this
          module perspective can infer the influence of functionally-related
          gene groups on complex traits, identify shared and unique
          transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict the impact of
          pharmacological perturbations on gene activity. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a shared latent representation. To achieve this, we integrate
          thousands of gene-trait associations (sourced from PhenomeXcan's TWAS
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and drug transcriptional profiles (from
          LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional
          space. This space is derived from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Our latent
          representation is defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those aligning with prior knowledge (pathways). In
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          find significant associations between diseases and gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types. Additionally, PhenoPLIER's
          capability to utilize models derived from large and diverse RNA-seq
          datasets allows us to identify modules associated with specific cell
          types under particular stimuli or disease states. We find that
          significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery
          cohort) are replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
          (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). We also
          conduct a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells,
          observing more robust trait associations with modules than with
          individual genes. Our module-based method outperforms a single-gene
          approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs. This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a superior means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Exploring the
          phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with
          relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with
          cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          conclusion, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          synergistically to perform different functions in specific cell types,
          rather than considering individual genes associated with different
          complex traits. This approach enhances the robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations, and we demonstrate how it can
          prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
          targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
          This approach represents a paradigm shift in the interpretation of
          genetic studies, holding potential to extract mechanistic insight from
          statistical associations to deepen our understanding of complex
          diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt

      response:
        output: >-
          In the realm of genetic studies, the need for a method that integrates
          varied data types into a unified analysis is evident (Context). We
          introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that offers a gene module
          perspective, enhancing our understanding of how functionally-related
          genes influence complex traits, and enabling the detection of shared
          and distinct transcriptomic characteristics among traits. By
          integrating thousands of gene-trait associations from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug-induced transcriptional
          profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a
          common latent representation, we can predict how changes in gene
          activity due to pharmacological interventions affect their functions.
          This integration leverages a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to
          extract gene modules that align with prior knowledge (pathways) from a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data. Our
          findings reveal that diseases are significantly associated with gene
          modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as T cells in
          hypothyroidism and different brain cell types in neuropsychiatric
          disorders. Moreover, the use of large RNA-seq datasets allows the
          identification of modules associated with cell types under specific
          conditions or disease states. These findings were replicated in the
          eMERGE network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. A CRISPR screen further
          demonstrated more robust trait associations with modules than with
          individual genes, suggesting a better prediction of FDA-approved
          drug-disease links via a module-based approach. This approach revealed
          stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, providing a
          fresh perspective on drug-disease relationships (Content). In sum,
          PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in interpreting genetic
          studies, prioritizing groups of functionally-related genes over
          individual genes. This method improves the robustness of detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations and offers a promising avenue for
          identifying alternative therapeutic targets when known single-gene
          associations are not detected, thereby enhancing our understanding of
          complex diseases and their treatment modalities (Conclusion).

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that
          provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. Our method's
          versatility allows the integration of different data types into a
          single representation for a comprehensive analysis. This approach
          enables the inference of how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, the identification of shared and unique
          transcriptomic properties among traits, and the prediction of the
          effects of pharmacological perturbations on gene activity. PhenoPLIER
          consolidates gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a shared latent representation by integrating thousands
          of gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000) into a
          low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on
          numerous RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a matrix factorization
          approach to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules
          with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those aligning
          with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations
          to this reduced expression space, we find that diseases are
          significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell
          types. Importantly, PhenoPLIER can utilize models derived from large
          and diverse RNA-seq datasets, enabling the identification of modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We also found that significant module-trait associations in
          PhenomeXcan were replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and
          Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. Additionally, we performed a
          CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells and found
          more robust trait associations with modules than with individual
          genes. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method
          also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs. This enhanced drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a more effective way to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Lastly, an
          exploration of the phenotype-module space revealed stable trait
          clusters associated with relevant tissues. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER
          not only considers individual genes associated with complex traits but
          also incorporates groups of genes that act together in specific cell
          types. This approach enhances the robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations and can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets. This method represents a
          significant shift in the interpretation of genetic studies and holds
          the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
          associations, thereby enhancing our understanding of complex diseases
          and their therapeutic strategies.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach to genetic
          studies that focuses on gene modules (Context). This method allows for
          the integration of different data types into a unified analysis,
          enabling the inference of how groups of related genes influence
          complex traits, the detection of shared and unique transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and the prediction of how drug-induced
          changes affect gene activities. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. This is accomplished by
          integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (as identified by
          TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space. This
          space is derived from public gene expression data from tens of
          thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]), using a
          matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that defines a latent representation.
          This representation extracts gene modules with certain sparsity
          constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge
          (pathways). We find that diseases are significantly associated with
          gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. For instance,
          hypothyroidism is associated with T cells, corneal endothelial cells
          with keratometry measurements, and neuropsychiatric disorders with
          different brain cell types. Additionally, PhenoPLIER can identify
          modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
          states. Using this approach, we have found that significant
          module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) were
          replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE)
          network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). We also
          performed a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells,
          observing more robust trait associations with modules than with
          individual genes (Content). In conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a
          shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, moving from
          considering individual genes to focusing on groups of genes that work
          together in specific cell types. This approach enhances our ability to
          detect and interpret genetic associations and prioritize promising
          candidate targets, even when known single gene associations are not
          detected. It offers the potential to extract mechanistic insights from
          statistical associations, thereby improving our understanding of
          complex diseases and their treatment options (Conclusion).

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the

          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of

          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.

          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature

          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles

          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like

          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities

          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological

          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;

          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the

          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In the realm of genetic studies, a comprehensive understanding of how
          groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits is
          paramount (Context). This paper introduces PhenoPLIER, an innovative
          approach that integrates diverse data sets for a holistic analysis. By
          mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a common latent representation, PhenoPLIER enables the
          inference of how certain gene groups affect complex traits, discerns
          shared and unique transcriptomic properties among traits, and predicts
          how pharmacological interventions impact gene activity. To achieve
          this, we amalgamate thousands of gene-trait associations from
          PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and transcriptional profiles
          of drugs from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Our method
          uses a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to extract gene modules with specific
          sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior
          knowledge (pathways). We discovered that diseases are significantly
          associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as
          T cells for hypothyroidism and different brain cell types for
          neuropsychiatric disorders. Additionally, our approach enables the
          identification of modules associated with cell types under specific
          stimuli or disease states. We also found that significant module-trait
          associations in PhenomeXcan replicated in the Electronic Medical
          Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
          [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225].
          Furthermore, our module-based method outperforms single-gene
          approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms (Content). In
          conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in genetic studies
          as it prioritizes groups of genes over individual genes, enhancing the
          robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic associations. This
          approach offers potential in unearthing mechanistic insights from
          statistical associations, thereby improving our understanding of
          complex diseases and their therapeutic strategies (Conclusion).

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In the field of genetic studies, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel
          method that adopts an omnigenic approach and focuses on gene modules.
          This method is versatile, enabling the integration of various data
          types into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. We
          demonstrate that this module-centric approach can deduce how clusters
          of functionally allied genes impact complex traits, discern shared and
          unique transcriptomic characteristics among traits, and predict the
          effect of drug-induced changes on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves
          this by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a shared latent representation. This
          involves integrating thousands of gene-trait associations, sourced
          from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083], and drug
          transcriptional profiles, obtained from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], into a low-dimensional space. This
          space is derived from publicly available gene expression data from a
          large number of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We employ a
          matrix factorization approach to define a latent representation
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003].
          This approach extracts gene modules under specific sparsity
          constraints and gives preference to those aligned with prior knowledge
          (pathways). Notably, we find that diseases are significantly linked
          with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Furthermore,
          PhenoPLIER can utilize models derived from large and heterogeneous
          RNA-seq datasets to identify modules associated with specific cell
          types under certain stimuli or disease states. We also confirm the
          replication of significant module-trait associations in the eMERGE
          network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. Our module-based approach
          outperforms the single-gene approach in predicting FDA-approved
          drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological
          mechanisms linked with the drugs' action mechanisms. This suggests
          that gene modules may provide a more effective way to explore
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. In conclusion,
          PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in interpreting genetic
          studies. By focusing on gene modules rather than individual genes, it
          enhances the robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations. This approach could potentially provide deeper insights
          into complex diseases and their treatment strategies by prioritizing
          promising candidate targets, even when known single-gene associations
          are not detected.

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model openai=gpt-4-0613
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
          offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our method's
          adaptability facilitates the integration of various data types for a
          unified analysis. Through this module perspective, we can deduce how
          groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits,
          identify shared and unique transcriptomic characteristics among
          traits, and predict the impact of pharmacological interventions on
          gene activity. PhenoPLIER aligns gene-trait associations and
          drug-induced transcriptional responses within a common latent
          representation. We achieve this by integrating thousands of gene-trait
          associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional
          profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space
          derived from public gene expression data on numerous RNA-seq samples
          (recount2). We utilize a latent representation defined by a matrix
          factorization approach that extracts gene modules with certain
          sparsity constraints and preferences for those that coincide with
          prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to
          this reduced expression space, we find that diseases are significantly
          associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types.
          Additionally, PhenoPLIER's ability to use models derived from
          extensive and diverse RNA-seq datasets allows us to identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We note that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our
          discovery cohort) are replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and
          Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III (our replication cohort). We also
          conduct a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells,
          observing more robust trait associations with modules than with
          individual genes. Our module-based method outperforms a single-gene
          approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the drugs'
          mechanism of action. This enhanced drug-disease prediction implies
          that modules may offer a superior method to examine drug-disease
          relationships than individual genes. Exploring the phenotype-module
          space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues,
          including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular,
          autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER
          considers groups of genes that function together in specific cell
          types, rather than single genes associated with different complex
          traits. This approach enhances the robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations, and we demonstrate its potential to
          prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
          targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
          This represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic
          studies, with the potential to extract mechanistic insight from
          statistical associations, thereby enhancing our understanding of
          complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the

          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic method that
          offers a gene module perspective for genetic research (Context). This
          approach integrates diverse data types into a unified representation
          for joint analysis, enabling the inference of how functionally-related
          gene groups influence complex traits, the detection of shared and
          distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and the prediction of
          pharmacological perturbations' effects on gene activity. By mapping
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation, PhenoPLIER integrates thousands
          of gene-trait associations (from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional drug profiles (from
          LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional
          space derived from public gene expression data (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We employ a
          matrix factorization approach to define a latent representation that
          extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints, favoring
          those that align with prior knowledge (pathways)
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003].
          Diseases are found to be significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types, such as T cells for hypothyroidism
          and different brain cell types for neuropsychiatric disorders. The
          utility of PhenoPLIER is further demonstrated through its capacity to
          identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
          disease states and its superior prediction of FDA-approved
          drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological
          mechanisms linked with the drugs' mode of action (Content). Notably,
          our study reveals that PhenoPLIER can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected, suggesting that gene modules may
          provide a more effective means to examine drug-disease relationships
          than individual genes. This signifies a conceptual shift in the
          interpretation of genetic studies, potentially enhancing our
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities
          (Conclusion).
