          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that offers a
          gene module perspective to genetic studies, thereby enhancing our
          understanding of complex traits and disease etiology (Context). This
          approach leverages the flexibility of integrating different data types
          for a comprehensive analysis, and it maps gene-trait associations and
          drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
          representation. To achieve this, we incorporate thousands of
          gene-trait associations and drug transcriptional profiles into a
          low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on
          numerous RNA-seq samples [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
          @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. Utilizing a matrix factorization approach, we
          extract gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences
          for those aligning with prior knowledge (pathways)
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]. We
          find that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types, and we can identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          Our findings are replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and
          Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (Content). Furthermore, our
          module-based approach outperforms a single-gene approach in predicting
          FDA-approved drug-disease links, suggesting that modules may provide a
          better means to examine drug-disease relationships. This approach also
          reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues,
          offering insights into the clustering of complex traits. In essence,
          PhenoPLIER emphasizes the collective action of gene groups in specific
          cell types over individual genes in interpreting genetic associations,
          providing a potential avenue for identifying promising therapeutic
          targets and understanding drug mechanisms (Conclusion). This
          represents a paradigm shift in the interpretation of genetic studies,
          with the potential to derive mechanistic insights from statistical
          associations, thereby advancing our understanding of complex diseases
          and their therapeutic modalities.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic methodology
          that employs a gene module perspective in genetic research (Context).
          This innovative approach allows for the integration of varying data
          types into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. By
          mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a shared latent representation, PhenoPLIER can discern
          how groups of functionally related genes impact complex traits,
          identify shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits,
          and predict the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene
          activity. This is achieved by integrating thousands of gene-trait
          associations from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a low-dimensional space derived
          from public gene expression data from a large number of RNA-seq
          samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
          @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). This latent representation is defined by a
          matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
          specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
          with prior knowledge (pathways). Notably, we found that diseases are
          significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell
          types, such as T cells in hypothyroidism and different brain cell
          types in neuropsychiatric disorders. Moreover, PhenoPLIER's ability to
          use models derived from large and diverse RNA-seq datasets allows us
          to identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli
          or disease states. Our findings in PhenomeXcan were replicated in the
          Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
          [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and we
          further validated our results via a CRISPR screen analyzing lipid
          regulation in HepG2 cells (Content). In conclusion, PhenoPLIER
          represents a significant shift in the interpretation of genetic
          studies, moving away from individual genes to groups of genes that
          work collectively within specific cell types. Our approach not only
          enhances the robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations but also allows for the prioritization of alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets when known single gene
          associations are not detected. This potential to extract mechanistic
          insights from statistical associations can greatly improve our
          understanding of complex diseases and their treatment modalities
          (Conclusion).

              Genes operate within context-specific networks to perform various
              functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Changes in these
              genes can alter their functional roles and, on a broader scale,
              impact biological processes related to disease
              [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this regard, understanding
              how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic
              comprehension of expression regulation across diverse cell types
              [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
              @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This understanding should
              subsequently lead to the development of improved treatments
              [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior
              studies have described various regulatory DNA elements
              [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
              @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
              @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including the genetic effects on

            text: >-
              Genes operate within specialized networks to perform distinct
              functions, and alterations in these genes can modify their roles,
              ultimately impacting disease-related biological processes
              [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6] (Context). To comprehend how
              genes affect complex traits, it is crucial to understand the
              regulation of gene expression across diverse cell types. This
              understanding could pave the way for enhanced treatments
              [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
              @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489] (Content). Previous research
              has delineated various regulatory DNA elements and genetic
              influences on gene expression across different tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
              @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
              @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
              Moreover, the integration of functional genomics data and
              genome-wide association study (GWAS) data has improved the
              detection of transcriptional mechanisms. When these mechanisms are
              disrupted, they often result in disease specific to certain
              tissues and cell lineages [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
              @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;

            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),

              Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks
              to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045;

              biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this

              mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across

              In the intricate world of genetics, genes do not operate in

              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. This sets the stage for the
              necessity to understand how these genes influence complex traits,
              a task that requires an in-depth comprehension of gene expression
              regulation across different cell types. This understanding holds
              promise for enhancing treatment strategies
              [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
              @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9; @doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous research has revealed
              various regulatory DNA elements, including the effects of genetics
              on gene expression across multiple tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
              @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
              @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The
              integration of functional genomics data and Genome-Wide
              Association Study (GWAS) data has significantly advanced the
              identification of these transcriptional mechanisms. When these
              mechanisms are disrupted, they often lead to pathology specific to
              particular tissues and cell lineages
              [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
              @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890;
              @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].
              However, a comprehensive understanding of how these genetic
              associations are projected through gene expression patterns
              remains elusive, highlighting a critical gap that this manuscript
              aims to address.

              Genes operate collectively within specific networks to perform
              various functions, a dynamic that is influenced by genetic
              variations [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. These variations can modify the
              roles of individual genes and, on a broader scale, impact
              biological processes related to disease. Understanding how genes
              contribute to complex traits necessitates a mechanistic
              comprehension of gene expression regulation across diverse cell
              types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9].

              improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Prior research has identified
              various regulatory DNA elements, including those that influence
              gene expression across different tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
              @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;

          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_21
            text: >-
              With the widespread availability of gene expression data across
              numerous tissues, an effective approach to identifying biological
              processes is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS)
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              These studies integrate expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data, providing a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. The
              basis of TWAS is to test whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has proven highly successful,
              not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome
              level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433] but also in predicting disease risk (using
              polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and
              repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, a limitation of
              TWAS is that it operates at the individual gene level, thereby
              failing to capture more complex interactions at the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

            text: >-
              The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
              offered a wealth of resources for understanding biological
              processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]
              (Context). A popular tool to decipher these processes is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide
              insights into the mechanisms behind genome-wide association study
              (GWAS) results. Essentially, TWAS investigates if alterations in
              gene regulation mediate the link between genetic variations and
              human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has proven fruitful not only
              in elucidating disease causes at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433], but also in predicting disease risk (polygenic
              scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] (Content). However, the current TWAS model
              focuses on individual genes, thereby overlooking potential
              intricate interactions at the network level, a gap that our
              manuscript aims to address (Conclusion).

              The advent of gene expression data across a multitude of tissues
              has opened new avenues in biological research
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              Among the methods developed to leverage this data, the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has proven effective.
              TWAS integrates data on expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              to provide mechanistic explanations for findings from genome-wide
              association studies (GWAS). It does so by examining the potential
              mediating role of gene regulatory mechanisms in the relationship
              between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              approach has been instrumental not only in understanding disease
              origins at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these successes, a significant gap
              remains in our understanding: TWAS operates at the level of
              individual genes, thereby overlooking potentially intricate
              interactions occurring at the network level.

              ---

              With the accessibility of gene expression data across various
              tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) presents
              an effective approach to identify these biological processes. This
              approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data, providing a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide
              Association Study (GWAS) findings. TWAS is dependent on the
              testing of whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms
              mediate the association between genetic variants and human
              diseases. These methods have proven highly effective not only in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, but
              also in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores and in
              drug repurposing tasks. However, it should be noted that TWAS
              operates at the individual gene level, which does not account for
              more complex interactions at the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining

              The advent of gene expression data from various tissues has opened

              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these successes, a limitation of
              TWAS is its focus on individual genes, which overlooks potential
              complex interactions at the network level. This paper addresses
              this gap by exploring the implications of such network-level
              interactions.

              # capture current references in the output using a regex

              output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)


              n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in
              references])

              return (n_fake_refs == 0)


              ---

              With the advent of gene expression data across a range of tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s13040-020-00216-9],
              new methods have been developed to identify biological processes.
              One such method, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS),
              utilizes expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
              interpret the mechanisms behind Genome-Wide Association Study
              (GWAS) findings. TWAS assesses whether changes in gene regulation
              can explain the link between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              approach has been highly effective in understanding disease
              origins at the level of the transcriptome [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting
              disease risk using polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level and therefore does not account for more intricate
              interactions at the network level. This gap in our understanding
              underscores the need for new approaches that can capture these
              complex interactions.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the

              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following

              ---

              With the broad availability of gene expression data across various
              tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has
              emerged as an effective approach for identifying biological
              processes. This method integrates expression quantitative trait
              loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of
              Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings. The TWAS approach
              tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
              the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases.
              These strategies have proven highly successful, not only in
              comprehending disease etiology at the transcriptome level but also
              in predicting disease risk (through polygenic scores) and in tasks
              related to drug repurposing. However, a limitation of TWAS is its
              focus on the individual gene level, which overlooks more complex
              interactions occurring at the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              The advent of comprehensive gene expression data from various
              tissues has opened new avenues in understanding biological
              processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. One such
              approach, the Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS),
              leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer

              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk (through polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, a significant limitation of TWAS
              is its focus on individual genes, thereby neglecting the intricate
              interactions that occur at the network level. This knowledge gap
              underscores the need for studies that can capture these complex
              interactions.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the

              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The

              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;

              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              The availability of gene expression data across various tissues
              has provided a valuable resource for identifying biological

              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A

              association study (TWAS). This approach integrates expression
              quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, offering a mechanistic
              interpretation of GWAS findings. TWAS tests whether alterations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms serve as a mediator in the association
              between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

              at the network level.

              The widespread availability of gene expression data across various
              tissues has paved the way for innovative research methodologies
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].

              (TWAS), a powerful tool that combines expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer mechanistic insights into the
              results of genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This approach
              tests the hypothesis that alterations in gene regulation
              mechanisms could explain the association between genetic variants
              and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Notably, TWAS has proven effective in
              elucidating disease origins at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk through polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these successes, there is an unmet
              need to extend the scope of TWAS beyond the individual gene level
              to capture more complex interactions at the network level.

              Given the accessibility of gene expression data across various
              tissues, one effective strategy for identifying biological
              processes is through a transcription-wide association study (TWAS)
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              This method integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. The
              effectiveness of TWAS lies in its ability to test whether
              disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship
              between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
              approaches have proven highly successful in not only understanding
              disease origins at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk through polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, the limitation of TWAS is that it
              operates at the individual gene level, and does not account for
              more complex interactions at the network level.

              The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
              opened up new avenues for understanding biological processes
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              One such promising approach is the transcription-wide association
              study (TWAS), which makes use of expression quantitative trait
              loci (eQTLs) data to offer mechanistic insights into the findings
              of genome-wide association studies (GWAS). This approach tests the
              hypothesis that changes in gene regulatory mechanisms could
              explain the link between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
              proven highly effective not only in shedding light on disease
              causes at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk (through polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and in identifying new uses for
              existing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, a key limitation
              of TWAS is its focus on individual genes, which overlooks the
              potentially more complex interactions that occur at the network
              level. This manuscript aims to address this gap by exploring the
              interplay of genes at a network level.

            text: >-
              A vast amount of gene expression data across various tissues is
              now readily available [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. To decipher the biological
              processes within this data, scientists have been using a method
              called a transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This
              approach combines data from expression quantitative trait loci
              (eQTLs) to provide a mechanistic explanation for the results of
              genome-wide association studies (GWAS). TWAS methods test if
              disturbances in gene regulation are the link between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Their successful application has not only

              improved disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, one limitation of TWAS is its
              focus on individual genes, which overlooks the potential for more
              intricate interactions at the network level.

              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_39
            text: >-
              Transcription-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) operate on the
              principle of testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases. Numerous studies have demonstrated the high
              success of this approach in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level, as well as in disease risk prediction
              (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks. Given the abundance
              of gene expression data across various tissues, TWAS proves to be
              an effective method for identifying these biological processes.
              This approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci
              (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for
              Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings. However, it
              should be noted that TWAS operates at the individual gene level,
              and therefore, does not capture more complex interactions at the
              network level.

            text: >-
              The transcription-wide association study (TWAS) is a crucial tool
              in modern genetic studies that investigates the link between
              genetic variations and human diseases by examining changes in gene
              regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method has proven to be highly
              effective, not only in enhancing our understanding of disease
              origins at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk (using polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs for new
              therapeutic targets [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The wealth of gene
              expression data across various tissues further bolsters the
              utility of TWAS [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. Despite these successes, a
              significant limitation of TWAS is its focus on individual genes,
              which overlooks the more intricate interactions that occur at the
              network level of gene co-expression. This study aims to address
              this gap by exploring the complex trait clustering through gene
              expression patterns.

            text: >-
              Transcription-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) are predicated on
              the testing of whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
              mediate the connection between genetic variants and human
              diseases. This approach has proven to be highly successful not
              only in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level,
              but also in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores and
              facilitating drug repurposing tasks. The availability of gene
              expression data across numerous tissues enables the effective use
              of TWAS to identify these biological processes. This method
              integrates Expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs) data,
              providing a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide Association
              Studies (GWAS) findings. However, it should be noted that TWAS
              operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more
              complex interactions at the network level.

              level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
              network level.

            namedScores: *ref_47
            text: >-
              Transcription-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) are predicated on
              the testing of whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
              mediate the association between genetic variants and human
              diseases. These approaches have proven highly successful in not
              only understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level,
              but also in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores, and
              in drug repurposing tasks. With the availability of gene
              expression data across numerous tissues, TWAS has emerged as an
              effective method for identifying these biological processes. It
              does so by integrating Expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs)
              data, providing a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide
              Association Study (GWAS) findings. However, it's important to note
              that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, and therefore
              does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

              The field of genetics has relied significantly on
              Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) to examine how
              changes in gene regulation could explain the link between genetic
              variations and human diseases[@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889]. This approach has proven
              successful not only in illuminating the causes of diseases at the
              transcriptome level[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk through polygenic
              scores[@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and identifying new uses
              for existing drugs[@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The widespread
              availability of gene expression data across various tissues has
              made TWAS an effective tool for discerning these biological
              processes[@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              However, a critical limitation of TWAS is its focus on individual
              genes, which obscures the more complex interactions that occur at
              the network level. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge
              gap.

            text: >-
              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are reliant on the
              evaluation of whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms
              serve as a mediator in the relationship between genetic variants
              and human diseases. This methodology has proven to be highly
              effective in not only understanding the etiology of diseases at
              the transcriptome level, but also in predicting disease risk
              through polygenic scores and in tasks related to drug repurposing.
              With the availability of gene expression data across numerous
              tissues, TWAS provides an efficient approach to identifying these
              biological processes. This method integrates expression
              quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a
              mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association studies
              (GWAS) findings. However, it should be noted that TWAS operates at
              the individual gene level and may not fully capture the complexity
              of interactions occurring at the network level.

            text: >-
              The exploration of genetic associations with human diseases often
              involves investigating disruptions in gene regulation mechanisms,
              a process facilitated by transcription-wide association studies
              (TWAS) [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
              studies have significantly contributed to our understanding of
              disease origins at the level of gene expression, or the
              transcriptome [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433]. In addition, they have proven valuable in
              predicting disease risk through polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and in identifying potential new
              uses for existing drugs, a practice known as drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The growing accessibility of gene
              expression data from various tissues further enhances the utility
              of TWAS [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              However, a limitation of current TWAS approaches is that they
              typically focus on individual genes, thereby overlooking the
              potentially more complex relationships that exist at the network
              level. This manuscript addresses this gap by exploring the role of
              gene co-expression in disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

              The study of gene regulatory mechanisms and their association with
              human diseases has been revolutionized by the use of

              development, has proven effective in advancing our understanding
              of disease origins at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. In addition to

              also been used successfully in predicting disease risk (via
              polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and

              expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. However, despite the strengths
              of TWAS, its focus on individual genes limits its ability to
              capture the complexity of interactions at the network level,
              highlighting a potential area for future research and development.

            text: >-
              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are based on testing
              the extent to which perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
              mediate the correlation between genetic variants and human
              diseases. This approach has proven highly successful in not only
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, but
              also in predicting disease risk using polygenic scores, and in
              drug repurposing tasks. With the wide availability of gene
              expression data across numerous tissues, TWAS emerges as an
              effective method to identify these biological processes. This
              approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data, providing a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide
              association study (GWAS) findings. However, it's important to note
              that TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not
              capture more complex interactions occurring at the network level.

              Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a powerful tool
              for exploring the links between genetic variations and human
              diseases by examining disruptions in gene regulation
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              approach has proven effective in illuminating disease origins on a
              molecular level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk using polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and identifying new uses for
              existing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The availability of gene
              expression data across various tissues further enhances the
              utility of TWAS [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. However, the current TWAS
              framework primarily focuses on individual genes, thereby
              overlooking potential complex interactions at the network level.
              This limitation underscores the need for more comprehensive
              methodologies to fully exploit the potential of TWAS in
              understanding disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

              interactions that occur at the network level. This highlights a

              understanding of complex genetic networks in disease etiology.

          - pass: false
            score: 0.8571428571428571
            namedScores: *ref_62
            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              ("however" in output.split(".")[-2].lower())

              ---

              The availability of gene expression data across various tissues
              allows for the use of transcription-wide association studies
              (TWAS) as an effective approach to identify biological processes
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              These studies integrate expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data, providing a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings.
              However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not
              account for complex network-level interactions. The method
              involves testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Despite this limitation, these approaches
              have been remarkably successful in not only understanding disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk (via polygenic scores)

              ---

              In the era of abundant gene expression data across various tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9],
              the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an
              effective tool for identifying biological processes. TWAS
              integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
              offer mechanistic explanations for genetic findings associated
              with diseases. Despite its effectiveness, TWAS operates on an
              individual gene level, thus not fully encompassing the intricate
              interactions that occur at the network level. TWAS's methodology
              hinges on testing if disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms
              serve as a bridge between genetic variations and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              approach has been notably successful in not only deepening our
              understanding of disease causation at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433], but also in predicting disease risk (polygenic
              scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these achievements, there remains
              a gap in capturing complex gene interactions at the network level,
              which our manuscript aims to address.

              The abundance of gene expression data across various tissues

              disease and drug mechanisms [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1038/s13040-020-00216-9;

              study (TWAS), which uses expression quantitative trait loci
              (eQTLs) data to interpret the findings of genome-wide association
              studies (GWAS). This approach has proven successful in
              understanding disease causation at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk using polygenic scores

              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] (Content). However, TWAS primarily focuses
              on individual genes, neglecting the more intricate interactions
              that occur at the network level. Consequently, there is an unmet
              need to incorporate network-level interactions into genetic
              studies to better elucidate disease processes and drug mechanisms
              (Conclusion).

              With the current abundance of gene expression data across various
              tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) presents
              an effective method for identifying biological processes. This
              approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data, providing a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide
              Association Study (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS operates at the
              level of individual genes and fails to capture more intricate
              interactions at the network level. It tests whether perturbations
              in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between
              genetic variants and human diseases. These approaches have been
              highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at
              the transcriptome level but also in predicting disease risk (via
              polygenic scores) and in drug repurposing tasks.

            text: >-
              The extensive availability of gene expression data across various
              tissues sets the stage for a deeper understanding of biological
              processes [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
              prevalent method for deciphering these processes is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This technique
              combines data on expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) to
              offer mechanistic explanations for findings from genome-wide
              association studies (GWAS). Despite its efficacy, TWAS operates on
              a single gene level and does not account for more intricate
              network-level interactions. The approach hinges on examining
              whether disturbances in gene regulatory mechanisms serve as a
              bridge between genetic variations and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              method has proven highly successful in not only comprehending
              disease origins at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], but also in
              predicting disease risk (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, the limitation of TWAS in
              capturing complex network-level interactions underscores the need
              for approaches that can probe these intricate relationships.

              The advent of extensive gene expression data across various
              tissues has paved the way for advanced biological process

              This approach utilizes expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data to offer mechanistic explanations for findings from
              genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Despite its effectiveness,
              TWAS primarily operates at the individual gene level, failing to
              account for more intricate network-level interactions. The method
              hinges on testing if alterations in gene regulation mechanisms
              serve as a conduit between genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This

              and repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, there is a
              pressing need to enhance the scope of TWAS to encapsulate
              network-level interactions, thereby enriching our understanding of
              complex biological processes and disease mechanisms.
