      - outputs:
          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_80
            text: >-
              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that
              offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our method's
              flexibility enables the integration of various data types into a
              unified representation for combined analysis. We demonstrate that
              this module perspective can deduce how clusters of
              functionally-related genes affect complex traits, identify shared
              and unique transcriptomic characteristics among traits, and
              predict the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene
              activity. PhenoPLIER consolidates gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a shared latent
              representation. To achieve this, we incorporate thousands of
              gene-trait associations (sourced from PhenomeXcan's TWAS
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data of
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We
              employ a latent representation, defined by a matrix factorization
              approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003], that extracts gene modules with
              specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those aligning
              with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
              associations to this reduced expression space, we find that
              diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed
              in relevant cell types. For example, hypothyroidism with T cells,
              corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
              hematological assays with specific blood cell types, plasma lipids
              with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different
              brain cell types. Additionally, as PhenoPLIER can utilize models
              derived from extensive and diverse RNA-seq datasets, we can also
              identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli
              or disease states. We note that significant module-trait
              associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) are replicated
              in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network
              phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). We
              also conduct a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2
              cells, noting more robust trait associations with modules than
              with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved
              in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. In
              comparison to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
              better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
              tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
              mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
              traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
              prediction suggests that modules may provide a superior means to
              examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Lastly,
              exploration of the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait
              clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
              branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER incorporates
              groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions
              in specific cell types, rather than focusing on single genes
              associated with different complex traits. This approach enhances
              robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
              we demonstrate its ability to prioritize alternative and
              potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
              single gene associations are not detected. This method signifies a
              conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, with
              the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations to improve our understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            latencyMs: 28487

          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_79
            text: >-
              In the context of genetic studies, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a
              comprehensive method that adopts a modular approach to
              understanding gene function and interaction. Our method combines
              various data types for a unified analysis, enabling the inference
              of how functionally-linked gene groups influence complex traits,
              the identification of shared and distinct transcriptomic
              characteristics among these traits, and the prediction of how drug
              interventions impact gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by
              mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
              responses into a shared latent representation, integrating
              thousands of gene-trait associations from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional profiles
              from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a
              low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene
              expression data [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. This latent representation, defined by a
              matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003], extracts gene modules under
              specific constraints, favoring those that align with established
              knowledge. We find that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Additionally, our
              approach allows for the identification of modules linked with cell
              types under specific conditions or disease states. Importantly, we
              find that our module-trait associations replicated in the eMERGE
              network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and that our module-based
              method outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting
              FDA-approved drug-disease associations, suggesting that modules
              may be a superior means to explore drug-disease relationships.
              Finally, we reveal stable trait clusters associated with relevant
              tissues, indicating a complex relationship between lipids and
              cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
              conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in the
              interpretation of genetic studies, focusing on groups of genes
              that work together within specific cell types. This approach
              enhances the robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic
              associations, offering the potential to reveal more promising
              candidate targets for therapeutic interventions and advance our
              understanding of complex diseases.

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific

              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation

            text: >-
              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel method for genetic
              analysis that offers a comprehensive view of gene modules, or
              groups of functionally-related genes, and their influence on
              complex traits (Context). Our approach incorporates different data
              types into a unified analysis, allowing us to discern shared and
              unique transcriptomic properties among traits and predict the
              impact of drug interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves
              this by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common representation. This is
              accomplished by integrating thousands of gene-trait associations
              from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug
              transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a low-dimensional space
              derived from public gene expression data on numerous RNA-seq
              samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We utilize a latent representation
              defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that identifies gene modules under certain constraints and
              preferences for those that align with established knowledge
              (pathways). Our results demonstrate that diseases are
              significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant
              cell types, and we can identify modules associated with cell types
              in specific disease states or under particular stimuli. Our
              findings using PhenoPLIER were replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. We
              also conducted a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
              HepG2 cells, further validating our module-based approach.
              Notably, PhenoPLIER outperformed single-gene methods in predicting
              FDA-approved drug-disease links, suggesting that gene modules may
              offer a more effective way to examine drug-disease relationships
              (Content). In conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a significant
              advancement in genetic studies by focusing on gene modules rather
              than individual genes. This approach enhances the robustness of
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations and can highlight
              alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets, even
              when known single gene associations are not detected. This
              innovation could lead to a deeper understanding of complex
              diseases and their therapeutic options, signifying a paradigm
              shift in genetic research (Conclusion).

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          - >-
            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression,
            therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
          - has proper last paragraph structure
          - >-
            Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns

      - outputs:
          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_77
            text: >-
              In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic tool that
              brings a gene module perspective to genetic research. Our method
              is flexible and capable of integrating different data types into
              one representation for a comprehensive analysis. We demonstrate
              that this module perspective can deduce how clusters of
              functionally-related genes affect complex traits, identify shared
              and unique transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict the
              influence of pharmacological interventions on gene activity.
              PhenoPLIER aligns gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses in a shared latent representation. To
              accomplish this, we incorporate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional
              profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space,
              derived from publicly available gene expression data from tens of
              thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a latent
              representation defined by a matrix factorization approach that
              isolates gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this compressed expression
              space, we note that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as T cells
              with hypothyroidism, and corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, among others. Notably, PhenoPLIER can
              utilize models derived from large and diverse RNA-seq datasets,
              allowing us to also identify modules associated with cell types
              under specific stimuli or disease conditions. We found that
              significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our
              discovery cohort) were replicated in the Electronic Medical
              Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III (our replication
              cohort). Additionally, we conducted a CRISPR screen to analyze
              lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, observing that trait associations
              were more robust with modules than with individual genes. Compared
              to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links more accurately by capturing
              tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
              drugs' mechanism of action. This suggests that modules may be more
              effective in examining drug-disease relationships than individual
              genes. Finally, our exploration of the phenotype-module space
              revealed stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues.
              In conclusion, PhenoPLIER offers a novel approach in interpreting
              genetic studies by focusing on groups of genes that work together
              in specific cell types rather than individual genes. This approach
              enhances the robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
              associations, and we demonstrate its potential in prioritizing
              alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets, even
              when known single gene associations are not detected. This
              represents a significant shift in the interpretation of genetic
              studies and has the potential to provide mechanistic insights from
              statistical associations, thereby enhancing our understanding of
              complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ("PhenoPLIER" in output.split(".")[0])

              ---

              In the realm of genetic studies, the need for a method that
              integrates varied data types into a unified analysis is evident
              (Context). We introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that offers a
              gene module perspective, enhancing our understanding of how
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, and enabling
              the detection of shared and distinct transcriptomic
              characteristics among traits. By integrating thousands of
              gene-trait associations from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug-induced transcriptional
              profiles from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a
              common latent representation, we can predict how changes in gene
              activity due to pharmacological interventions affect their
              functions. This integration leverages a matrix factorization
              approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to extract gene modules that
              align with prior knowledge (pathways) from a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data. Our findings reveal that
              diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed
              in relevant cell types, such as T cells in hypothyroidism and
              different brain cell types in neuropsychiatric disorders.
              Moreover, the use of large RNA-seq datasets allows the
              identification of modules associated with cell types under
              specific conditions or disease states. These findings were
              replicated in the eMERGE network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. A
              CRISPR screen further demonstrated more robust trait associations
              with modules than with individual genes, suggesting a better
              prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease links via a module-based
              approach. This approach revealed stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, providing a fresh perspective on
              drug-disease relationships (Content). In sum, PhenoPLIER
              represents a paradigm shift in interpreting genetic studies,
              prioritizing groups of functionally-related genes over individual
              genes. This method improves the robustness of detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations and offers a promising avenue
              for identifying alternative therapeutic targets when known
              single-gene associations are not detected, thereby enhancing our
              understanding of complex diseases and their treatment modalities
              (Conclusion).
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              exec:python
              /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
              --model openai=gpt-4-0613
            latencyMs: 17979

            namedScores: *ref_81
            text: >-
              In the realm of genetic studies, we introduce a novel approach
              termed PhenoPLIER, which utilizes an omnigenic perspective to
              analyze gene modules. This method is flexible, permitting the
              integration of various data types into a unified representation
              for joint analysis. We demonstrate that this approach can deduce
              the influence of functionally-related gene clusters on complex
              traits, discern shared and unique transcriptomic properties among
              traits, and predict the impact of pharmacological perturbations on
              gene activity. To achieve this, PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait
              associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a
              shared latent representation. This process involves integrating
              thousands of gene-trait associations from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and drug transcriptional profiles
              from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a
              low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on
              an extensive collection of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We
              employ a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules with
              specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those aligning
              with prior knowledge. By mapping gene-trait associations to this
              reduced expression space, we reveal significant associations
              between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell
              types. Notably, PhenoPLIER's ability to utilize models derived
              from large, heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets allows the
              identification of modules associated with specific cell types
              under particular stimuli or disease states. We found that
              significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan replicated in
              the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase
              III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225].
              Furthermore, our module-based approach outperforms a single-gene
              approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by
              capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms associated
              with drug actions. This enhanced drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may offer a superior means to investigate
              drug-disease relationships than individual genes. In conclusion,
              PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in the interpretation of
              genetic studies. By focusing on groups of genes that act together
              within specific cell types, rather than single genes associated
              with complex traits, we improve the robustness of detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations. Our findings illustrate how
              this approach can prioritize alternative and potentially more
              promising candidate targets even when known single gene
              associations are not detected, thereby deepening our understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

      - outputs:
          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_82
            text: >-
              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
              offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our approach
              is flexible, allowing for the integration of various data
              modalities into a unified representation for joint analysis. We
              demonstrate that this module perspective can infer the influence
              of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify
              shared and unique transcriptomic properties among traits, and
              predict the impact of pharmacological perturbations on gene
              activity. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a shared latent representation. To
              achieve this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations
              (sourced from PhenomeXcan's TWAS [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083])
              and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space.
              This space is derived from public gene expression data on tens of
              thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Our
              latent representation is defined by a matrix factorization
              approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
              specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those aligning
              with prior knowledge (pathways). In mapping gene-trait
              associations to this reduced expression space, we find significant
              associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in
              relevant cell types. Additionally, PhenoPLIER's capability to
              utilize models derived from large and diverse RNA-seq datasets
              allows us to identify modules associated with specific cell types
              under particular stimuli or disease states. We find that
              significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our
              discovery cohort) are replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
              and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). We
              also conduct a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2
              cells, observing more robust trait associations with modules than
              with individual genes. Our module-based method outperforms a
              single-gene approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links
              by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked
              with the mechanism of action of drugs. This improved drug-disease
              prediction suggests that modules may provide a superior means to
              examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.
              Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
              associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
              involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER incorporates
              groups of genes that act synergistically to perform different
              functions in specific cell types, rather than considering
              individual genes associated with different complex traits. This
              approach enhances the robustness in detecting and interpreting
              genetic associations, and we demonstrate how it can prioritize
              alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even
              when known single gene associations are not detected. This
              approach represents a paradigm shift in the interpretation of
              genetic studies, holding potential to extract mechanistic insight
              from statistical associations to deepen our understanding of
              complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
