            text: >-
              In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach to
              genetic studies that focuses on gene modules (Context). This
              method allows for the integration of different data types into a
              unified analysis, enabling the inference of how groups of related
              genes influence complex traits, the detection of shared and unique
              transcriptomic properties among traits, and the prediction of how
              drug-induced changes affect gene activities. PhenoPLIER achieves
              this by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common latent representation.
              This is accomplished by integrating thousands of gene-trait
              associations (as identified by TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space. This space is derived from public gene
              expression data from tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples
              (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]), using a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that defines a latent representation. This representation extracts
              gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for
              those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). We find that
              diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed
              in relevant cell types. For instance, hypothyroidism is associated
              with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
              measurements, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain
              cell types. Additionally, PhenoPLIER can identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. Using this approach, we have found that significant
              module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort)
              were replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
              (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). We
              also performed a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
              HepG2 cells, observing more robust trait associations with modules
              than with individual genes (Content). In conclusion, PhenoPLIER
              represents a shift in the interpretation of genetic studies,
              moving from considering individual genes to focusing on groups of
              genes that work together in specific cell types. This approach
              enhances our ability to detect and interpret genetic associations
              and prioritize promising candidate targets, even when known single
              gene associations are not detected. It offers the potential to
              extract mechanistic insights from statistical associations,
              thereby improving our understanding of complex diseases and their
              treatment options (Conclusion).
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              In the field of genetic studies, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel
              method that adopts an omnigenic approach and focuses on gene
              modules. This method is versatile, enabling the integration of
              various data types into a unified representation for comprehensive
              analysis. We demonstrate that this module-centric approach can
              deduce how clusters of functionally allied genes impact complex
              traits, discern shared and unique transcriptomic characteristics
              among traits, and predict the effect of drug-induced changes on
              gene activity. PhenoPLIER achieves this by mapping gene-trait
              associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a
              shared latent representation. This involves integrating thousands
              of gene-trait associations, sourced from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083], and drug transcriptional profiles,
              obtained from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], into
              a low-dimensional space. This space is derived from publicly
              available gene expression data from a large number of RNA-seq
              samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We employ a matrix factorization approach
              to define a latent representation [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]. This approach extracts gene
              modules under specific sparsity constraints and gives preference
              to those aligned with prior knowledge (pathways). Notably, we find
              that diseases are significantly linked with gene modules expressed
              in relevant cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can utilize models
              derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets to identify
              modules associated with specific cell types under certain stimuli
              or disease states. We also confirm the replication of significant
              module-trait associations in the eMERGE network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. Our
              module-based approach outperforms the single-gene approach in
              predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
              tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
              drugs' action mechanisms. This suggests that gene modules may
              provide a more effective way to explore drug-disease relationships
              than individual genes. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER represents a
              paradigm shift in interpreting genetic studies. By focusing on
              gene modules rather than individual genes, it enhances the
              robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic associations.
              This approach could potentially provide deeper insights into
              complex diseases and their treatment strategies by prioritizing
              promising candidate targets, even when known single-gene
              associations are not detected.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          - >-
            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression,
            therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
          - has proper last paragraph structure
          - >-
            Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
            highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
      - outputs:
          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_84
            text: >-
              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that
              provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. Our
              method's versatility allows the integration of different data
              types into a single representation for a comprehensive analysis.
              This approach enables the inference of how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, the
              identification of shared and unique transcriptomic properties
              among traits, and the prediction of the effects of pharmacological
              perturbations on gene activity. PhenoPLIER consolidates gene-trait
              associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a
              shared latent representation by integrating thousands of
              gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and
              transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000) into a
              low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on
              numerous RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a matrix
              factorization approach to define a latent representation that
              extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those aligning with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we find that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Importantly,
              PhenoPLIER can utilize models derived from large and diverse
              RNA-seq datasets, enabling the identification of modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We also found that significant module-trait associations
              in PhenomeXcan were replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
              and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. Additionally, we
              performed a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2
              cells and found more robust trait associations with modules than
              with individual genes. Compared to a single-gene approach, our
              module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease
              links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms
              linked with the mechanism of action of drugs. This enhanced
              drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a more
              effective way to examine drug-disease relationships than
              individual genes. Lastly, an exploration of the phenotype-module
              space revealed stable trait clusters associated with relevant
              tissues. In conclusion, PhenoPLIER not only considers individual
              genes associated with complex traits but also incorporates groups
              of genes that act together in specific cell types. This approach
              enhances the robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
              associations and can prioritize alternative and potentially more
              promising candidate targets. This method represents a significant
              shift in the interpretation of genetic studies and holds the
              potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations, thereby enhancing our understanding of complex
              diseases and their therapeutic strategies.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              ("PhenoPLIER" in output.split(".")[0])

              ---

              In the realm of genetic studies, a comprehensive understanding of
              how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits
              is paramount (Context). This paper introduces PhenoPLIER, an
              innovative approach that integrates diverse data sets for a
              holistic analysis. By mapping gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation, PhenoPLIER enables the inference of how certain
              gene groups affect complex traits, discerns shared and unique
              transcriptomic properties among traits, and predicts how
              pharmacological interventions impact gene activity. To achieve
              this, we amalgamate thousands of gene-trait associations from
              PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and transcriptional
              profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a low-dimensional space
              learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
              RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). Our method uses a matrix factorization
              approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] to extract gene modules with
              specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
              with prior knowledge (pathways). We discovered that diseases are
              significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant
              cell types, such as T cells for hypothyroidism and different brain
              cell types for neuropsychiatric disorders. Additionally, our
              approach enables the identification of modules associated with
              cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We also found
              that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
              replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE)
              network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. Furthermore, our module-based
              method outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms (Content). In conclusion, PhenoPLIER
              represents a paradigm shift in genetic studies as it prioritizes
              groups of genes over individual genes, enhancing the robustness of
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations. This approach
              offers potential in unearthing mechanistic insights from
              statistical associations, thereby improving our understanding of
              complex diseases and their therapeutic strategies (Conclusion).
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the

              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_91
            text: >-
              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic
              methodology that employs a gene module perspective in genetic
              research (Context). This innovative approach allows for the
              integration of varying data types into a unified representation
              for comprehensive analysis. By mapping gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a shared latent
              representation, PhenoPLIER can discern how groups of functionally
              related genes impact complex traits, identify shared and distinct
              transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict the effects of
              pharmacological interventions on gene activity. This is achieved
              by integrating thousands of gene-trait associations from
              PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and transcriptional
              profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049] into a low-dimensional space
              derived from public gene expression data from a large number of
              RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
              @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). This latent representation is defined by
              a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
              specific sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
              with prior knowledge (pathways). Notably, we found that diseases
              are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
              relevant cell types, such as T cells in hypothyroidism and
              different brain cell types in neuropsychiatric disorders.
              Moreover, PhenoPLIER's ability to use models derived from large
              and diverse RNA-seq datasets allows us to identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. Our findings in PhenomeXcan were replicated in the
              Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225], and
              we further validated our results via a CRISPR screen analyzing
              lipid regulation in HepG2 cells (Content). In conclusion,
              PhenoPLIER represents a significant shift in the interpretation of
              genetic studies, moving away from individual genes to groups of
              genes that work collectively within specific cell types. Our
              approach not only enhances the robustness of detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations but also allows for the
              prioritization of alternative and potentially more promising
              candidate targets when known single gene associations are not
              detected. This potential to extract mechanistic insights from
              statistical associations can greatly improve our understanding of
              complex diseases and their treatment modalities (Conclusion).
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          - >-
            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
          - >-
            genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression,
            therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
          - has proper last paragraph structure
          - >-
            Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
            highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
      - outputs:
          - pass: true
            score: 1
            namedScores: *ref_88
            text: >-
              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
              offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our method's
              adaptability facilitates the integration of various data types for
              a unified analysis. Through this module perspective, we can deduce
              how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits,
              identify shared and unique transcriptomic characteristics among
              traits, and predict the impact of pharmacological interventions on
              gene activity. PhenoPLIER aligns gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses within a common latent
              representation. We achieve this by integrating thousands of
              gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and
              transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000) into a
              low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on
              numerous RNA-seq samples (recount2). We utilize a latent
              representation defined by a matrix factorization approach that
              extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that coincide with prior knowledge
              (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced
              expression space, we find that diseases are significantly
              associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types.
              Additionally, PhenoPLIER's ability to use models derived from
              extensive and diverse RNA-seq datasets allows us to identify
              modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
              disease states. We note that significant module-trait associations
              in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) are replicated in the
              Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              (our replication cohort). We also conduct a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, observing more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes. Our
              module-based method outperforms a single-gene approach in
              predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
              tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
              drugs' mechanism of action. This enhanced drug-disease prediction
              implies that modules may offer a superior method to examine
              drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In conclusion, PhenoPLIER considers groups of genes that function
              together in specific cell types, rather than single genes
              associated with different complex traits. This approach enhances
              the robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations,
              and we demonstrate its potential to prioritize alternative and
              potentially more promising candidate targets even when known
              single gene associations are not detected. This represents a
              conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, with
              the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical
              associations, thereby enhancing our understanding of complex
              diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel approach that
              offers a gene module perspective to genetic studies, thereby
              enhancing our understanding of complex traits and disease etiology
              (Context). This approach leverages the flexibility of integrating
              different data types for a comprehensive analysis, and it maps
              gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
              into a common latent representation. To achieve this, we
              incorporate thousands of gene-trait associations and drug
              transcriptional profiles into a low-dimensional space derived from
              public gene expression data on numerous RNA-seq samples
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083; @doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]. Utilizing
              a matrix factorization approach, we extract gene modules with
              certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those aligning
              with prior knowledge (pathways) [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]. We find that diseases are
              significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant
              cell types, and we can identify modules associated with cell types
              under specific stimuli or disease states. Our findings are
              replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE)
              network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (Content). Furthermore, our
              module-based approach outperforms a single-gene approach in
              predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links, suggesting that
              modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships. This approach also reveals stable trait clusters
              associated with relevant tissues, offering insights into the
              clustering of complex traits. In essence, PhenoPLIER emphasizes
              the collective action of gene groups in specific cell types over
              individual genes in interpreting genetic associations, providing a
              potential avenue for identifying promising therapeutic targets and
              understanding drug mechanisms (Conclusion). This represents a
              paradigm shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, with the
              potential to derive mechanistic insights from statistical
              associations, thereby advancing our understanding of complex
              diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We

              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use

              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and

              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our

              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust

              In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic method
              that offers a gene module perspective for genetic research
              (Context). This approach integrates diverse data types into a
              unified representation for joint analysis, enabling the inference
              of how functionally-related gene groups influence complex traits,
              the detection of shared and distinct transcriptomic properties
              among traits, and the prediction of pharmacological perturbations'
              effects on gene activity. By mapping gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation, PhenoPLIER integrates thousands of gene-trait
              associations (from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and
              transcriptional drug profiles (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
              derived from public gene expression data (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We
              employ a matrix factorization approach to define a latent
              representation that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity
              constraints, favoring those that align with prior knowledge
              (pathways) [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]. Diseases are found to be
              significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant
              cell types, such as T cells for hypothyroidism and different brain
              cell types for neuropsychiatric disorders. The utility of
              PhenoPLIER is further demonstrated through its capacity to
              identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli
              or disease states and its superior prediction of FDA-approved
              drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological
              mechanisms linked with the drugs' mode of action (Content).
              Notably, our study reveals that PhenoPLIER can prioritize
              alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even
              when known single gene associations are not detected, suggesting
              that gene modules may provide a more effective means to examine
              drug-disease relationships than individual genes. This signifies a
              conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies,
              potentially enhancing our understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities (Conclusion).

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
